channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.title: ã€How Remix is shaking things upã€‘æ··éŸ³å¦‚ä½•æ‘‡åŠ¨
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹738 â€” May 30, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Wake Up, Remix! Everything's Changing.. â€” Big news from the Remix camp this week. About a year ago, Remix and React Router merged together reflecting their shared goals and code, but now itâ€™s all change again. React Router is now basically what Remix originally intended to be, and so â€˜Remixâ€™ is rebooting as a model-first, low-dependency, Web API-centric full-stack framework built on Preact. Itâ€™ll no longer be a 'React framework' perÂ se.

Michael Jackson and Ryan Florence

ğŸ•’Â The Upcoming Temporal API and What Problems It Will Solve â€” The Temporal API has been cooking for many years now as a new way to work with dates and times in JavaScript. Itâ€™s just been enabled in Firefox 139 by default and sure to come to more runtimes ASAP. Hereâ€™s why it matters and what itÂ offers.

Suren Enfiajyan

CodeRabbitâ€™s Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf â€” Code Rabbit brings AI code reviews to VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf. Get line-by-line reviews, one-click fixes & codebase-aware feedback - all free in your IDE. Seamlessly integrates with git workflows. Install the extension & startÂ reviewing!

CodeRabbit sponsor

Announcing Angular v20 â€” A big release for the Google backed framework where a lot of the more recent experimental features (like signals and incremental hydration) have received a lot of polish and been promoted as stable. There are new experimental APIs too, including resource streaming and httpResource for making HTTP requests with a signal-based reactiveÂ API.

Minko Gechev

ğŸ’¡ While the official release post (above) is packed with content, you might appreciate this brief magic-themed roundup of what's new in AngularÂ 20.

IN BRIEF:

  • Matteo Collina has unveiled php-node, a way to run PHP apps within the same process as Node.js. Run WordPress with a Next.js frontend?Â Sure.

  • TC39's 108th meeting is currently taking place with many proposals being advanced, such as Seeded Pseudo-Random Numbers moving to stage 2 and Error.isError moving to stageÂ 4.

  • The OpenJS Foundation is now a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) for over 40 popular JavaScript projects it hosts, including ESLint, Express, andÂ Electron.

  • Node's technical steering committee has decided against instituting an official bounty program.

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.2.15 â€“ Gains a bun audit tool for performing security audits of projectÂ dependencies.

  • Ink 6.0 â€“ Use React to build CLIÂ apps. Now supporting ReactÂ 19.

  • Docusaurus v3.8 â€“ Popular docs-oriented static site generator.

  • Ember 6.4, JSPM 4.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

Why Are 2025/05/28 and 2025-05-28 Different Days in JavaScript? â€” An interesting â€˜Watâ€™-like moment in just the first few lines of this post, which Brandon decided to dig into andÂ explain.

Brandon Dong

â–¶Â Â Modern Performance Debugging in Chrome DevTools â€” Paul shares a look at the reimagined Chrome DevTools Performance panel, showing off new features, how they work, and how to use them to make performanceÂ gains.

Paul Irish

Build an LMS SaaS App from Scratch â€” Learn to build a production-ready AI SaaS using Next.js with auth, billing, and an AI voiceÂ agent.

Clerk sponsor

React, Visualized: A Visual Exploration of React Concepts â€” The creators of a React course have updated their popular visual explainer of numerous core React concepts to cover React 19 and features like actions, transitions, and Server ComponentsÂ too.

Tyler McGinnis et al.

â–¶Â Â The 3 Ways JavaScript Frameworks Render the DOM â€” The creator of the SolidJS framework looks at the different approaches frameworks take to render what they produce. A good look under the hood that isnâ€™t too complex. (16Â minutes.)

Ryan Carniato

Build a Blog with Angular in Under 30 Minutes Using Analog â€” Analog is a meta-framework for Angular (think along the lines of Next.js orÂ Nuxt).

Peter Mbanugo

Your React Meta-Framework Feels Broken, Here's Why â€” â€œSometimes youâ€™ve got to burn it all down, start from ash, and rebuild from first principles. This is what we did withÂ RedwoodSDK.â€

Redwood Team

ğŸ“„ No Server, No Database: Smarter Related Posts in Astro with Transformers.js Alexander Opalic

ğŸ“„ A Thought on JavaScript 'Proof of Work' Anti-Scraper Systems Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Multithreading in JavaScript with Web Workers Badmus Kola

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Svelte Flow 1.0: Create Node-Based UIs and Diagrams in Svelte â€” From the creators of the similar React Flow comes a customizable Svelte component for building node-based editors and interactive diagrams. WantÂ examples?

webkid GmbH

Cap: A Lightweight, Modern Open Source CAPTCHA Alternative â€” This solution boasts a method called â€œproof-of-workâ€ which attempts to make automated CAPTCHA solving more expensive. It uses a Web Component and you can try out a few demos here. GitHubÂ repo.

Cap

Enterprise Requirements Slowing You Down? Thereâ€™s a Better Way â€” WorkOS lets devs ship SSO, SCIM, audit logs & moreâ€”fast. Trusted by industry-leading teams like OpenAI, Vercel &Â Plaid.

WorkOS sponsor

Google Gen AI SDK for TypeScript and JavaScript v1 â€” Why let Python developers have all the fun? Now you can harness the full power of Googleâ€™s Gemini API (and Vertex platform) from Node.jsÂ too.

Google

ReactJust: Server Components Without a Framework â€” If, for some reason, you donâ€™t want to adopt a full-scale framework like Next.js or React Router to use or experiment with RSCs, this â€˜vanilla RSCâ€™ approach could be ofÂ interest.

almadoro

  • NeutralinoJS 6.1 â€“ Lightweight cross-platform desktop appÂ framework.

  • Linkify 4.3 â€“ Turn links, hashtags, and mentions in text to HTMLÂ links.

  • image-type 6.0 â€“ Detect the image type of a Buffer/Uint8Array.

  • Faker 9.8 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • file-type 21.0 â€“ Detect the file type of a file, stream, orÂ data.

  • Mineflayer 4.29 â€“ Create Minecraft bots inÂ JavaScript.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

How Notionâ€™s engineering team tackled viral user growth to run PostgreSQL at scale on Amazon RDS withÂ pganalyze.

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere..

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • The annual Stack Overflow Developer Survey is back for a fifteenthÂ year.

  • A Minecraft-style building experience in pure CSS â€“ no JavaScript atÂ all!

  • Simon Willison writes about how GitHub Issues works really well as a personal notebook for taking notes, linking them together, and generally organizing whatever sort of information you want. It doesn't have to just be for codeÂ projects.

  • I just discovered that Matthias Bynens, who you might know for his work on everything V8, ECMAScript specs, and more, keeps a repo of the 'smallest possible syntactically valid files' in many differentÂ formats.

  • Did you know you can style alt text like any other text on WebÂ pages?

item.title: ã€Big Node, VS Code, and Mantine updatesã€‘å¤§èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œvsä»£ç å’Œå£ç‚‰æ›´æ–°
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹735 â€” May 9, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

k6 1.0: Go-Powered Load Testing with JavaScript â€” A full-featured, configurable load generation tool that uses the Sobek Go-powered JavaScript engine to support writing test scripts in JavaScript. v1.0 promises stability, first-class TypeScript support, and betterÂ extensibility.

Grafana Labs

JSON-Powered White-Label Form Builder for Your JavaScript App â€” Build dynamic JSON-driven forms in your JavaScript application with SurveyJS â€” a fully customizable, drag-and-drop form-building UI component. It integrates seamlessly with React, Angular, and Vue 3, and has no backend limitations. Perfect for form-heavyÂ apps.

SurveyJS sponsor

Node 24 (Current) Released â€” Nodeâ€™s release lines are shifting a little lately â€“ v18 has gone EOL and now v23 gives way to v24 as the â€˜Currentâ€™ release for when you need the cutting edge features. It comes with npm 11, V8 13.6 (hello RegExp.escape, Float16Array, and Error.isError), the URLPattern API exposed by default, plus UndiciÂ 7.

Node.js Team

ğŸ’¡ Technically, Node v24.0.1 is the latest version temporarily reintroducing an EOL feature due to breakages in popularÂ dependencies.

Visual Studio Code Version 1.100 â€” Not to be confused with a 1.1 release, this update to VS Code has quite a few goodies for JavaScript developers with improved â€˜Next Edit Suggestionsâ€™ that will suggest adding missing imports, support for Nodeâ€™s enhanced network debugging capabilities, improved visibility of type information, remote MCP server support, GPT 4.1 as the new default base model, andÂ more.

Microsoft

IN BRIEF:

  • The Node.js team is keen for you to take the latest Node.js Next 10 survey to help guide Node's futureÂ priorities.

  • Polycompiler uses a cute trick to let you merge Python and JavaScript into the same sourceÂ file.

  • The OpenJS Foundation has announced its new board of directors.

RELEASES:

  • ğŸ¤– ESLint v9.26.0 â€“ An interesting release for the popular static analysis tool as it adds support for MCP as a way for ESLint to be used directly by AI models and codingÂ agents.

  • ğŸ—¾ Mapbox GL JS 3.12 â€“ Interactive, customizable vector maps in the browser, rendered withÂ WebGL.

  • Relay v19 â€“ Facebook's declarative React/GraphQLÂ framework.

  • Material UI 7.1 â€“ React components using MaterialÂ Design. Now Tailwind CSSÂ 4Â compatible

  • Rspack 1.3.9, Babylon.js 8.7, Electron 36 (official blogÂ post)

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

The Power of the Spread and Rest Syntax â€” A quick run through the opportunities opened up with just three little dots ...

Matt Smith

React Server Components for Astro Developers â€” Astroâ€™s â€˜islandâ€™ architecture and React Server Components share a strikingly similar mental model. Dan compares the two, digs into some of the quirks, and suggests Astro offers a â€˜gentler onrampâ€™ to some of RSCâ€™s ideas if youâ€™re struggling withÂ them.

Dan Abramov

Wallaby MCP: Deep Runtime Context for Your AI Agent â€” Wallaby gives your AI agent live execution data, dynamic coverage, and real-time insights to fix and generate tests, and write code withÂ confidence.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Migrating a Project from Prettier and ESLint to Biome â€” Prettier and ESLint are staples in many JavaScript build processes, but Biome offers an interesting â€˜one stop shopâ€™ alternative.

Damilola Olatunji

ğŸ“„ 'Electron Ain't Bad, Actually' â€“ Worth re-reading next time you see the clichÃ©d criticisms ofÂ Electron. Vaxry

ğŸ“º The React Compiler Explained in Three Minutes Better Stack

ğŸ“„ You're Misunderstanding DDD in Angular Tomasz Ducin

ğŸ“„ The Story of Fastify + Vue Jonas Galvez

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

HelloCSV: A Drop-In, CSV Importing Workflow for JS Apps â€” If you or your users have CSV files to import, hereâ€™s a complete CSV importing workflow for the frontend that you can drop into your app. BasicÂ docs.

HelloCSV

PptxGenJS 4.0: Build PowerPoint Presentations with JavaScript â€” A mature library that outputs standards-compliant Open Office XML files compatible with PowerPoint, Apple Keynote, and other common presentation tools. Supports graphics, text, tables, and other typical slide objects. Lots ofÂ demos.

Brent Ely

Introducing Clerk Billing â€” Clerk Billing lets you add B2C/B2B subscriptions with no payment code or UI workâ€”just drop in components andÂ go.

Clerk sponsor

Mantine 8.0: The Full Featured React Components Library â€” Mantine is one of the most celebrated React components libraries, and for good reason: itâ€™s full featured, modern, and looks great. v8.0 ups its chart game with a little Recharts magic, adds over twenty new components (including a GitHub-style Heatmap, Tree and SemiCircleProgress), submenus, and muchÂ more.

Vitaly Rtishchev et al.

Hyparquet: Parquet File Parser for JavaScript â€” Parquet is a popular column-oriented data file format frequently used for storing large datasets for analysis. Hyparquet is a dependency-free JavaScript library for working with Parquet files, even in the browser (as in thisÂ demo).

Hyperparam

ğŸ”ŠÂ react-sounds: Add Sound Effects to React Apps â€” Having sound effects on the Web might sound like your idea of a nightmare, but this is a well put together project with delicate, well thought out examples that strike the rightÂ tone.

Aedilic Inc.

mono-jsx: <html> as a Response â€” A server-side JSX runtime that renders <html> to a Response with no build step needed and works across numerous server-side JSÂ runtimes.

Je Xia

  • Prisma v6.7 â€“ The popular ORM's attempts to move away from Rust to TypeScript are picking upÂ pace.

  • Slack Send GitHub Action 2.1 â€“ Send data into Slack from GitHubÂ Actions.

  • openid-client 6.5 â€“ OAuth 2/OpenID Connect client API for JSÂ runtimes.

  • ğŸ“„ DOCX 9.5 â€“ Generate Word documents fromÂ JavaScript.

  • eslint-plugin-prettier 5.4 â€“ Runs Prettier as an ESLintÂ rule.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸ•¹ï¸ Craft delightful games that change how the world learns as an engineer at Brilliant. Remote/NYC/SF:Â brilliant.org/careers/

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere..

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem we've noticed this week:

  • The CSS Overflow 5 spec enables the creation of pure CSS scroll and 'carousel' experiences on the Web, and Sara Soueidan has dug in deep and done an accessibility and usability analysis of the feature. Is it time to give up your JavaScript-based approach? Not yet, saysÂ Sara.

  • Sam Rose is back with another fantastic visual essay - this time looking at 'reservoir sampling.' As well as getting to learn a useful programming technique in a visual way, you can also check out all the JavaScript code he built that powers theÂ article.

  • One team decided to move away from Next.js and migrate to Ruby on Rails, while still maintaining a React frontend â€“ here's their tale of why and how.

  • Postgres 18 Beta 1 was released. IO performance on Linux is a bigÂ focus. The final release is due in September orÂ October.

  • ğŸ¤– Google has updated its Gemini 2.5 Pro model â€“ they claim it's now far better at building frontend apps in particular with 'a real taste for aesthetic webÂ development'.

P.S. If you're into React or Node.js, we focus more directly on those in React Status and Node Weekly respectively, so check out the latest issues of those tooÂ :-)

Dan Abramov

wallaby mcpï¼šaiä»£ç†çš„æ·±åº¦è¿è¡Œæ—¶ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ - wallabyå…è®¸æ‚¨çš„AI Agentå®æ—¶æ‰§è¡Œæ•°æ®ï¼ŒåŠ¨æ€è¦†ç›–èŒƒå›´å’Œå®æ—¶æ´å¯ŸåŠ›ï¼Œä»¥è§£å†³å’Œç”Ÿæˆæµ‹è¯•ï¼Œå¹¶ç½®ä¿¡å¤„ã€‚

ã€‚

wallabyå›¢é˜Ÿ

- åœ¨è®¸å¤šJavaScriptæ„å»ºè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œæ›´æ¼‚äº®ä¸”Eslintæ˜¯ä¸»é£Ÿï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ damilola olatunji

ğŸ“„ vaxry

ğŸ“ºğŸ“„ğŸ“„

mono-jsx: as a Response â€” A server-side JSX runtime that renders to a Response with no build step needed and works across numerous server-side JSÂ runtimes.

je xia

item.title: ã€A timeline of JavaScript's historyã€‘JavaScriptå†å²çš„æ—¶é—´è¡¨
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹737 â€” May 23, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Brief History of JavaScript â€” JavaScript (originally named LiveScript) turns thirty years old this year and the Deno team has put together a fantastic timeline-based tour of how much things have progressed from its first appearance in Netscape Navigator, through offshoots like JScript, standardization, and the introduction of Node.js, all the way through to the modernÂ day.

The Deno Team

2x-40x Faster Docker Builds with Blacksmith â€” With a one-line code change, Blacksmith can make your Docker builds incremental by mounting your Docker layer cache into your GitHub Actions runner. Blacksmith is used by 600+ companies like Ashby, Clerk, andÂ Mintlify.

Blacksmith sponsor

âš¡Â Announcing TypeScript Native Previews â€” Earlier this year, Anders Hejlsberg teased a 10x faster TypeScript through efforts being made to port the TypeScript compiler to Go, enabling it to be compiled and run natively, as well as take advantage of more concurrency. The good news is you can now give it a.. go forÂ yourself.

Microsoft

â–¶Â Â An Introduction to JavaScript Frameworks â€” The creator of SolidJS has put together a tight 11-minute video boiling down the different approaches taken by React, Angular, Vue, Svelte, and Solid. Dense, but a great way to get a lay of theÂ land.

Ryan Carniato

IN BRIEF:

  • Ryan Dahl responds to recent community chatter about the state of the Deno project in 'Reports of Deno's Demise Have Been Greatly Exaggerated'.

  • Guess the Output is a fun multi-choice JavaScript quiz to put your knowledge to the test. Each answer is explained as youÂ go.

  • A look at the agenda for next week's TC39 meeting, including the proposals up forÂ discussion.

  • React Router now has preview support for React Server Components.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v24.1.0 (Current) and v22.16.0 (LTS)

  • Bun v1.2.14 â€“ The fast JS runtime &Â toolkit.

  • Slonik v48 â€“ Node.js Postgres client with runtime & build time typeÂ safety.

  • Zod v4, Astro 5.8, ESLint v9.27.0

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

â–¶Â Â What's New in Angular â€” Two members of the Angular team presented a session at this weekâ€™s Google I/O event on the latest updates to the Angular framework in anticipation of the eventual release of Angular 20 nextÂ Thursday.

Chasanoff and Thompson (Google)

ESLint v9.0: A Retrospective â€” Itâ€™s been a year since ESLint v9.0 landed as the first major release in a few years. It enabled the new flat-config system by default and the rollout didnâ€™t go as smoothly as hoped. This retrospective breaks down the full story and shares the lessonsÂ learned.

Nicholas C. Zakas

Getting Started with Clerk Billing â€” Learn how to build a complete billing experience with Clerk and Stripe, no custom UI or webhooksÂ required.

Clerk sponsor

Six Ways Slack, Notion, and VS Code Improved Electron App Performance â€” An experienced Electron app developer shares a guide to Electron performance optimization and how to get the most out of yourÂ apps.

Amila Welihinda

ğŸ“„ How the at() Method Makes Array Indexing Easier Matt Smith

ğŸ“„ Styling Console Text in Node.js Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

ğŸ“„ Authenticating JavaScript WebSockets Steven Waterman

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Defuddle: Extract the Main Content from Web Pages â€” Strips extraneous clutter from HTML in order to leave only the primary content for you to format or use as you wish. Essentially a modern implementation of the ideas behind Mozillaâ€™s Readability. Thereâ€™s an online demo if you want to give it aÂ try.

Steph Ango

snapDOM: Captures DOM Nodes as Images â€” A fast and accurate DOM-to-image capture mechanism to capture any HTML element as a scalable SVG image, preserving styles, fonts, background images, etc.

ZumerLab

AI-Powered Code Reviews for JavaScript Teams â€” CodeRabbit helps you ship cleaner JavaScript by reviewing every PR with AI that understands yourÂ codebase.

CodeRabbit sponsor

ForesightJS: Predictive Mouse Intent Library â€” An interesting concept, with the entire page acting as a demo of sorts. The idea is to decrease latency by prefetching data or pages as soon as you think a user might be heading in that direction. Your mileage may vary and itâ€™s less useful for touchÂ devices.

ForesightJS, Inc.

Astra: A New JavaScript-to-EXE Compiler for Windows â€” Boasts â€œa new approach to compilingâ€ JavaScript applications for a single executable experience on Windows only (forÂ now).

QwertyCodeQC

Crosspost: A JS Utility for Posting Across Multiple Social Networks â€” Currently supports eight different services including Bluesky, X, Mastodon, andÂ LinkedIn.

Nicholas C. Zakas

Rockpack 6.0: An Alternative React App Starter â€” A tool aiming to get React project setup time as low as possible, complete with server side rendering support, bundling, linting and testing. v6.0 updates everything for React 19. GitHubÂ repo.

Alex Sergey

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ Calendar Link 2.10.0 â€“ Generate event links for popular calendarÂ services.

  • octokit.js 5.0 â€“ 'All-batteries-included' GitHub SDK for JavaScript.

  • image-type 6.0 â€“ Detect the image type of a Buffer/Uint8Array.

  • Peggy 5.0 â€“ Parser generator forÂ JavaScript.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Build a professional design system in less than a day, using Hope AI, new model by Bit.Cloud. Enjoy reusable UI components ready forÂ import.

ğŸ‘€Â  Elsewhere..

Here's a selection of things from the broader ecosystem this week:

  • Google's I/O event took place this week and â–¶ï¸Â its 'developer keynote' was a highlight, particularly when Addy Osmani showed off some of the latest Chrome DevTools fun (starting at about 30 minutes in).

  • Microsoft has unveiled a new Postgres extension for VS Code that brings IntelliSense completion to SQL, GitHub Copilot integration, a visual way to explore your schemas, andÂ more.

  • ğŸ¤– Anthropic has unveiled its new Claude 4 models. The Claude family of LLMs are quite heavily used by modern coding agents, as well as Claude's own now-generally-available Claude Code tool.

  • The Glitch platform, a popular way to build and host Node-backed webapps, is shutting down its app hosting functionality â€“ it seems uncertain quite what Glitch will or won't be afterÂ July.

ã€‘

Chasanoffå’ŒThompsonï¼ˆGoogleï¼‰

Nicholas C. Zakas

Amila Welihinda

  • Googleçš„â–¶qus'å¼€å‘äººå‘˜ä¸»é¢˜æ¼”è®²'æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªäº®ç‚¹ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯å½“Addy Osmaniå±•ç¤ºä¸€äº›æœ€æ–°çš„Chrome DevTools Fun æ—¶ï¼ˆä»å¤§çº¦30åˆ†é’Ÿå¼€å§‹ï¼‰ã€‚

item.title: ã€The power of generatorsã€‘å‘ç”µæœºçš„åŠ›é‡
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹736 â€” May 16, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

'I Think the Ergonomics of Generators is Growing on Me' â€” The author notes generator functions have been widely available in JavaScript for a long time, yet â€œtheir practicality hasnâ€™t exactly caught on.â€ This is a great look at what they are and where they can beÂ useful.

Alex MacArthur

JavaScript's New Superpower? Explicit Resource Management â€” V8 v13.8 introduces the idea of deterministic resource cleanup. Among a range of new symbols and objects for the task, the basic idea is you can wrap any file handle, stream or connection in a using/await using block and the runtime will handle any cleanup once resources go out ofÂ scope.

Rezvan Mahdavi Hezaveh (V8)

Write CSS Like a Pro â€” Kevin Powell shares how to create a responsive website from scratch using modern CSS features (such as nesting, utility classes, custom properties, and more). This detailed video course also dives into adding additional polish via animations, view transitions, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Basecoat: shadcn/ui's Magic, But Minus React â€” shadcn/ui is a popular suite of well designed React components, but if youâ€™d like to use them in other contexts too, Basecoat is for you. Basecoat ports the components to a more vanilla form you can use with your framework (or not) ofÂ choice.

Ronan Berder

IN BRIEF:

  • Did you know that console.log supports format strings? IÂ didn't!

  • The Deno team shares an update on the Fresh framework.

  • The Angular team is teasing the release of Angular 20 to be on May 29, but we might learn a lot more at Google I/O next week. I'm going to be there, say hi if you see me!Â :-)

  • Microsoft announced a round of layoffs this week and, much to the communityâ€™s disappointment, Ron Buckton, a key TypeScript contributor, was among thoseÂ affected.

  • Brian Clark shares some best practices for creating a modern npmÂ package.

RELEASES:

  • May 14 Security Releases of Node.js â€“ Including v24.0.2 (Current), v23.11.1 (Current), v22.15.1 (LTS), and v20.19.2 (LTS).

  • Nuxt 3.17 â€“ The full-stack Vue.js-based framework.

  • Parcel v2.15.0 â€“ The popular build tool gets a new transformer and minifier for HTML and SVG that also supports converting SVGs to JSX for use in ReactÂ components.

  • React Router 7.6, MUI X 8.3, Mithril.js 2.3

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

JavaScript, When (and What) is this? â€” Dives into the complexities of the this keyword, explaining how its value is ultimately determined by the context in which a function is called, rather than where itâ€™s defined. Itâ€™s been many years since weâ€™ve covered this elementary topic, but this is a fantastic, fresh two-partÂ take.

Mat 'Wilto' Marquis

How We Debugged a Broken Checkout Flow in Flask + React â€” Dropped carts = lost revenue. See how Sentry tracing can catch a full-stack bug in a Flask + React checkout flowâ€”before it can become a support fireÂ drill.

Sentry sponsor

Building a React App with GitHub Copilot â€” A good walkthrough, complete with video, if you prefer, of bringing together several of GitHub Copilotâ€™s features for building a modern JavaScript appÂ quickly.

Kedasha Kerr (GitHub)

Regular Expressions in JavaScript â€” Powerful but often misunderstood, many will benefit from this roundup of the potential regexes offer to JavaScriptÂ developers.

Adebayo Adams

ğŸ“„ Robust Data Fetching Architecture for Complex React/Next.js Apps Trevor I. Lasn

â–¶ï¸ Native and RxJS Observables: A Direct Comparison Rainer Hahnekamp

ğŸ“„ Angular's httpResource in the Wild â€“ A modern way to make HTTP requests inÂ Angular. DrDreo

ğŸ“„ Node.js 24 is Here: What You Need toÂ Know Lizz Parody

ğŸ“„ Building the Bridge: Running JavaScript Modules from Dart Chima Precious

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

ANSIS 4.0: ANSI Color Library for Everywhere â€” A library to use the power of ANSI escape sequences for coloring and styling text in many environments including the terminal, Chromium-based browsers, Node, Bun, Deno, and even Next.js. v4.0 is a big upgrade with enough breaking changes to warrant a migration guide for existingÂ users.

webdiscus

TanStack DB: A Reactive Client Store with Fast Real-Time Sync â€” A new entry to the TanStack family of libraries that extends TanStack Query with collections, live queries and optimisticÂ mutations.

TanStack

Introducing Clerk Billing â€” Set up subscriptions in your B2B or B2C app without writing custom payment code or building your ownÂ UI.

Clerk sponsor

Svelte Sonner: A Toast Notification Component for Svelte â€” You may be familiar with the fantastic Sonner in the React world â€“ now thereâ€™s a SvelteÂ version.

Robert Soriano

tscircuit: Use React for Building ElectronicsÂ Projects â€” An interesting way to design and lay out electronic circuit boards using a JSX-based approach. GitHubÂ repo.

tscircuit Inc.

jsdiff 8.0: A JavaScript Text Diffing Implementation â€” Can compare strings for differences in various ways including creating patches. Thereâ€™s an onlineÂ demo.

Kevin Decker

Feedsmith: A Fresh New Web Feed Parser and Generator â€” A new, modern way to both parse and generate RSS, Atom, JSON Feed, OPML, and RDF feeds with support for common namespaces as used in podcast, media, and other niche types of feed.

Maciej Lamberski

  • Faker 9.8 â€“ Generate fabricated data to your heart'sÂ content.

  • ngx-vflow 1.8 â€“ Angular library to create node-basedÂ apps.

  • ğŸ¨ color-convert 3.1 â€“ Plain color conversion functions.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Build a professional design system in less than a day, using Hope AI, new model by Bit.Cloud. Enjoy reusable UI components ready forÂ import.

ğŸ‘€Â This could be useful..

Fx 36.0: A Command-Line JSON Viewer & Processing Tool â€” It's written in Go, but if youâ€™ve got some files full of JSON that you want to slice and dice, Fx is for you (it's easy to install). This week's v36 release adds support for streaming JSON and tailing such streams, itâ€™s also much faster and less memory hungry when parsing large JSON files. A solid update for a handyÂ tool.

Anton Medvedev

P.S. If you're into React or Node.js, we focus more directly on those in React Status and Node Weekly respectively, so check out the latest issues of those tooÂ :-)
